content.description: Hard moves right from the get-go. Power your way up the proud arÃªte that overhangs the road by 8 feet. Most mortals will take advantage of the single bolt anchor up top for top-roping. Whether you TR or highball, plan on using some traffic control and avoid trying this during rush hour.
Start on the prow of the arete and move right toward the top on big holds. Quite easy, quite fun!
content.location: Trojan Boulder, immediately right of the Arete of Troy.

content.description:
Follow the striking line of pockets and holes up and left.

I start with my right hand in a good pocket and left on a higher positive edge. Other options exist, including a lower start. Climb through the two big holes and then stay focused on the crux top out.

There's a direct start on crimps to the left, V4.
content.location: Left side of the Trojan Boulder's east face. Right next to the road and just right of the Trojan Arete.

content.description:
Start low on big flat edge, then perform a series of hard, sustained, and aesthetic moves out right. Stay on the lower holds. Travel through the big pocket that marks the beginning of Heavy Traffic, then finish on Big Deal (V5).

Feels kinda like an eliminate, but climbs super clean. A must do.
content.location: Begins on the starting hold of the Trojan Arete, which is a large, flat edge at the far left of the boulder.

content.description: Start with a good right sidepull and left hand undercling. Up on edges to committing, heady top out.
content.location: Trojan Boulder, east face, right side

content.description: Starts to the left of heavy traffic and follows a series of crimps to join heavy traffic at the jug.
content.location: Left of heavy traffic. Right of trojan arete

content.description: A head's-up problem on good rock. For some reason, the holds remind me of the holds on Blitzkrieg. Anyways, start with hands on small stuff, head up and right. Top-out is on the insecure side and a bit funky, so get good spotters.
content.protection: Pads. I had several to level out the poor landing.
content.location: If you're facing the Trojan Boulder, look to the left of the Trojan Arete, and this is the first line on the left side of the big oak tree.

content.description: Start of Old Soft Hsu and traverse right all the way around the Troy Arete and into and up the rounded dihedral. I don't know if there is a proper name for this route, but it's a great way for those of us who like to stay close to the ground to play on the Trojan Boulder.
content.protection: pad plus spotter to move it

content.description:
Linkup of Heavy Traffic and Big Deal.

Start as for Heavy Traffic and move up to the second, bigger hole. Traverse right on edges into the Big Deal finish. Top out on cool slopers. Excellent!
The prominent north arete of the Trojan Boulder forms the rightmost boundary of the "Traffic Wall." This problem climbs the left side of the arete on good edges.

This is an evil, evil climb. I think it should be re-named "Three moves to Hell". The holds are small, the moves are big, and the crux demands a very particular body position. The crux is also the throw to the last hold, so with each try you have to do two big pulls just to get there.

An excellent and devious climb to be sure.
content.protection: One pad will do you fine.
content.location:
Start on the obvious crimp rail to the right of Heavy Traffic. Make a big first move up and right to a small gaston. Continue up the slightly bulging face.

The shorter-inclined will either need to do an extra move or two to reach the rail (and likely bump the grade a little in the process), or have to fold pads. I'm 6'0" and I can just reach.
